properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain changing to snow overnight. Significant snowfall possible on Friday. Total snowfall: generally 5 to 15 cm. Location: most of mainland Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow early Friday morning then taper off Friday afternoon. Total rainfall amounts may reach 25 mm over extreme southwestern Nova Scotia. The highest snowfall accumulations will be over eastern Nova Scotia, where snowfall warnings have been issued. Rapidly accumulating snowfall may impact the Friday morning commute in urban areas. Be prepared for reduced visibility at times in falling snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-19T16:42:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-19T00:43:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3550849311.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Friday. Accumulation: 15 to 20 cm. Location: Cape Breton and eastern mainland Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning and will taper off by Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be along the Atlantic coast and over higher terrain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-19T16:42:30-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 18, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory issued on March 16, 2021 for Vernon due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-20T02:01:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-19T10:02:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3428466863.2021
Area: North Okanagan

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 km/h. Locations: Postville - Makkovik Time span: ending this afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T17:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is possible over some areas. Locations: southwestern and western Newfoundland, Time span: early this morning until late this afternoon. Remarks: At this time only 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected, but there is some uncertainty with the forecast, with potential for higher amounts to shift into these regions. Should the weather system responsible for the snow shift westward, as much as 10 to 15 cm could fall in some areas. Please continue to monitor future forecasts in case snowfall warnings are required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T23:56:59-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: eastern and southeastern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, except 40 to 60 mm over the southern Avalon Peninsula and Burin Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Rain will transition to snow late this afternoon or this evening for the east coast. Meanwhile, a transition through freezing rain and ice pellets is expected over the Avalon Peninsula late this evening, before precipitation changes to snow after midnight. The rain, at times heavy, will be accompanied by mild temperatures resulting in significant snowmelt and runoff. Local flooding is possible, especially in areas with poor drainage. As temperatures fall tonight, areas of standing water will quickly freeze resulting in icy and slippery surfaces. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-20T04:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-19T13:32:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2588577864.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL March 18, 2021 08:00 - Kamloops) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
